message.entry: The following error occurred while simulating model ''{0}'' : {1} \n Try rerunning the simulation in normal mode to get more details about the error.
Clock with identifier {0} was not found at runtime.
Task with identifier {0} was not found at runtime.
Construction of classic simulation loop failed because of the following reason : {0}.
Dense timer cannot be used for the fixed-step simulation because the model has continuous rates.
Requested sequence with the given rate specification was not found.
Execution sequence or timeline ''{0}'' has no formal specification available.
Event {0} was broadcasted/raised again before its associated tasks have completed execution.
Execution loop detected for partition ''{0}''.
Fixed step simulation does not support specifying hit times.
Specified hit time {0} is less than the current time {1}.
The time of next hit ({0}) specified for the variable sample time (id={1}) is invalid because it is less than the current time ({2})
Simulation time will exceed the maximum double precision value for the next time step. Hence, the simulation is being stopped at time {0}.
There was an error installing signal handler.
A call was made to populate task table for multiple execution specification. This is not supported. For now, we just aggregate the task tables.
Start time for design is set to {0} while the start time for observer {1, number, integer} is set to {2}. Set them to be the same value.
A request was made to preempt currently active task with task ''{0}'' at time {1}, however, task ''{0}'' is not ready and cannot be scheduled to run at this time.

A request was made to preempt currently active task with task ''{0}'' at time {1}. Task ''{0}'' is ready to run, however, all runnable instances have already been executed and there are no runnable instances of this task left at this step. Therefore, the preemption request cannot be fulfilled.
A request was made to preempt currently active task with task ''{0}'' at time {1}. However, task ''{0}'' is already running.
A request was made to the scheduler to preempt currently running task and run task ''{0}'' at time {1}, however, task dispatch is not active, so the request to run cannot be fulfilled.
Timer {0} was advanced at time {1} but the earlier tick was the final tick of this timer. Timers should not be advanced after final tick.
Timer {0} was advanced at time {1} but it was already in advanced state and had a tick. A close must be called before calling advance again.
The resolution of timer {0} is being changed in middle of the step. This is not allowed.
The specified timer resolution {0} set for timer {2} is not an integer multiple of the resolution {1} of its parent timer.
The specified timer resolution {0} is not an integer fraction of the original resolution {1} for timer {2}.
The new timer resolution {0} is not a valid resolution.
The resolution of timer {0} cannot be tuned.
The resolution of timer {0} cannot be scaled.
The resolution {1} for timer {0} is non finite, negative or zero. Set the resolution to a strictly positive finite value.
The resolution scale factor {1} for timer {0} is non finite, negative or zero. Set the scale factor to a strictly positive finite value.
Resolution tuning constraint {1, number, integer} specified for timer {0} resolution is not valid.
Scheduler implementation used in the current simulation does not support event handling.
Scheduler implementation in use for current simulation does not support task preemption.
Simulation step size of {0} is smaller than the double precision eps {1} around time {2}. Hence, the simulation is being terminated.
Model stop time is set to infinity. Simulation may run forever.
Model stop time is set to NaN. Set the stop time to a finite positive value or inf.
Scheduled hit time {0} is less than the current time {1} for rate with index {2} and identifier {3}.

Number of ticks to the next hit for the controllable sample time (id={0}) at time {1} is specified as {2} that is not valid and hence, the next hit cannot be scheduled. Specify the number of ticks to next hit as a strictly positive integer.
